concept.title: Quick Start Step 4:
concept.shortdesc: During this step you will use Terraform to create a cluster on .

ol.li: Decompress the .tar.gz file into a convenient directory.
Navigate to the directory and ensure that it contains a .tfvars file. Your .tfvars file should contain the credentials and keys for your cluster.
Add the necessary information to the .tfvars file.For more information, see Terraform Variables.

Run the following command:terraform apply -var-file=<myVariables>.tfvars
Terraform creates the necessary security groups and VM instances, installs Docker, and the installs the Docker images required to run the NATS messaging system.

stentry.p: After the Docker image is deployed as an instance on , you can find out the core URL in of the following ways:
stentry.note: The URL will be formatted using the xip.io wildcard DNS, for example, api.15.125.91.46.xip.io

ul.li: Run the terraform show command to see the xip.io address.
On the web interface, click Project Compute Instances , note the external IP address (listed under the internal IP address), and format it as follows: api.<external IP address>.xip.io

stentry.p: You can view the container host security group by clicking Project Computer Access and Security .

ol.li: Navigate to the core URL in your browser.When you first connect to the core URL, your browser may warn you that the console is attempting to use a self-signed certificate, or that the site is not trusted. You can safely ignore these warnings or add the certificate to your certificate store.
Log into the console using the email and password you specified when you created the cluster.
